target.value: Proportion of the the population that is undernourished (in %)
(1990) Undernourishment statistics for the 1990 GHI are based on data from 1990 - 1992

Statistics taken from 'State of food insecurity in the world 2009', FAO 2009, and based on an average over a three-year period where available. Some statistics based on authors estimates: see data cube slices for details.
(2010) Undernourishment statistics for the 2010 GHI are based on data from 2004 - 2006
Prevelance of underweight in children under five (in %)
(1990) Child underweight statistics for the 1990 GHI are based on data from 1988 - 1992
(2010) Child underweight statistics for the 2010 GHI are based on data from 2003 - 2008
1990 Statistics are based on 'Global database on child growth and malnutrition', WHO, 2010. Some statistics based on authors estimates: see data cube slices for details.

2010 Statistics are based on 'Global database on child growth and malnutrition', WHO, 2010; 'Childinfo statistics on child nutrition.', UNICEF, 2010; and 'Demographic health surveys', MEASURE DHS, 2010. WHO 2010 is the primary data source and others are secondard. Some statistics based on authors estimates: see data cube slices for details.
Proportion of children dying before the age of five (in %)
(1990) Under five mortality statistics for the 1990 GHI are based on data from 1990
(2010) Under five mortality statistics for the 2010 GHI are based on data from 2008
Statistics taken from 'Tracking progress on child and maternal nutrition: A survival and development priority', UNICEF 2009"
Indicates whether or not the value is an estimate.

Normal is the default value (if no value is provided) and is used when no special coded qualification is assumed. Usually, in this case, it can be assumed that the source agency assigns sufficient confidence to the provided observation and/or the value is not expected to be dramatically revised.
Missing value - Global Hunger Index of less than 5

Data can be missing due to various reasons:  data do not exist, are insignificant (or not collected because they are below a certain threshold), are unreliable, are not relevant for the period, or other reason not elsewhere specified. In the Global Hunger Index, countries with the GHI of less than 5 are shown as '<5'. In the RDF dataset, this is registered as a missing value to keep a consistent data type for the GHI measure.
(1990) The 1990 GHI draws on data from 1988 - 1992
(2010) The 2010 GHI draws on data from 2003 - 2008

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is a tool adapted and further developed by the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) to compre- hensively measure and track global hunger.1 The GHI incorporates three interlinked hunger-related indicators – the proportion of under- nourished in the population, the prevalence of underweight in children, and the mortality rate of children.
The Global Hunger Index (GHI) is calculated by the weighted average of three measures. GHI = (PUN + PUW + U5MR)/3

The GHI is published annually based on data available at that time. Sometime the final GHI for a particular year will be revised in a later year based on improved access to data (so the 2011 GHI publication could update the 2010 GHI value. You should look for the most recent statistics by looking for the LastRevised property
Data and supporting data for the 2010 Global Hunger Index, including revised comparison data for 1990. An innovative, enhanced approach for measuring hunger and undernutrition.
Due to enhancements and revisions to the underlying data in the 2010 Global Hunger Index, figures are not directly comparable to previous years. See the 2010 GHI Report for more details.
